definitions.definition: wanting to do something or wanting something to happen very much
definitions.sensetop: keen to do somethingkeen for somebody/something to do somethingkeen that…keen on doing something

examples.text: John was very keen to help.
Her parents were keen for her to go to university.
examples.contextForm: keen for somebody/something to do something

examples.text: He is keen for the deal to proceed.
We are keen that our school should get involved too.
I wasn't too keen on going to the party.
She is extremely keen to remain with the police and we are equally keen to retain her.
The banks were not at all keen to lend to somebody who actually seemed to need money.
He was naturally keen to make a good impression.
She was always keen to hear the local gossip.
We are keen that Britain should get involved too.
They were desperately keen for information.
I waited a few days before putting in an offer on the property so as not to appear too keen.

definitions.definition: enthusiastic about an activity or idea, etc.

examples.text: a keen sportsman/gardener
one of the keenest supporters of the team
She was a star pupil—keen, confident and bright.

definitions.definition: liking somebody/something very much; very interested in somebody/something
definitions.sensetop: keen on somebody/somethingkeen on doing something

examples.text: They've been on a few dates together and Naomi seems really keen.
Tom's very keen on Anna.
He's particularly keen on football.
Sally's quite keen on the idea.
She's not keen on being told what to do.
a keen mind/intellect
a keen sense of tradition
He took a **keen interest** in his grandson's education.
Dogs have a **keen sense** of smell.
My friend has **a keen eye** for *(= is good at noticing)* a bargain.

definitions.definition: involving people competing very hard with each other for something

examples.text: There is keen competition for places at the college.
They were keen rivals.
It was the subject of keen debate.

definitions.definition: kept low in order to compete with other prices

examples.text: The company hopes its keen pricing policy will increase sales.

definitions.definition: having a sharp edge or point
wanting very much to do well at something; enthusiastic
liking something/somebody very much; very interested in something

examples.text: He's mad keen on planes.

wordOrigin: adjective Old English cēne ‘wise, clever’, also ‘brave, daring’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch koen and German kühn ‘bold, brave’. Current senses date from Middle English.
